Church means a building primarily used for public religious worship on a regular basis. Distilled spirits means any alcoholic beverages containing more than 21 percent alcohol by volume including, but not limited to, fortified wine. License means the authorization by the mayor and city council to engage in the sale of distilled spirits by the package not for consumption on the premises of the licensee. Licensee means any person, firm or corporation engaged in selling, at retail, any distilled spirits for beverage purposes in unbroken packages not for consumption on the premises of the licensee. Lounge means a separate room where malt beverages and/or wine are served by the drink which is either connected with or part of and is adjacent to a restaurant (as defined in this section) and operated in conjunction therewith and under the same management as the restaurant operations. No lounges shall be permitted. Malt beverage means any beer, ale or like beverage made from malt by fermentation which contains alcohol. Permit means the authorization by the mayor and city council for a wholesaler or wholesale distributor to engage in the wholesale sales of malt beverages and/or wine to retail licensees. Place of business means the premises described in the licenses issued pursuant to this chapter. Premises means location where licensee is authorized to sell alcoholic beverages. Private club means a corporation organized and existing under the laws of the state; actively in operation within the city at least one year immediately prior to the application for a license hereunder having at least 75 members regularly paying monthly, quarterly or semiannual dues, organized and operated exclusively for pleasure, recreation and other nonprofitable purposes, no part of the net earnings of which inures to the benefit of any shareholder or member and owning, hiring or leasing a building or space therein for the reasonable use of its members with suitable kitchen and dining room space and equipment and maintaining and using a sufficient number of servants and employees for cooking, preparing and serving meals at least five days a week for its members and guests. Such club shall also be an organization which has received and has maintained approval from the United States Internal Revenue Service as a bona fide section 501(c)(3) organization. The building of such club shall be air-conditioned and located in one of the following zoning districts of the city: C1 (Central Commercial District) or C2 (Neighborhood Commercial District). To qualify as a private club under this chapter, no member or officer, agent or employee of the club may be paid, or directly or indirectly receive, in the form of salary or other compensation, any profits from the sale of alcoholic beverages by the club to its members or guests beyond the amount of such salary as may be fixed by its members at any annual meeting or by its governing board out of the general revenue of the club. No license shall be issued to any location or maintained at any location that does not have adequate on-premises parking as required by the then applicable parking regulations of the city. No license shall be issued to any location or maintained at any location if the front entrance to the licensed premises is not clearly visible from a public street. Restaurant means any public or private place kept, used, maintained, advertised and held out to the general public as a place where meals are actually and regularly served, without sleeping accommodations. Such place shall be air-conditioned and contain adequate and sanitary kitchen and dining room equipment and seating capacity for at least 40 people, and have employed therein a sufficient number and kind of employees to prepare, cook and serve suitable food for its patrons. At least two meals per day shall be served at least four days a week, with the exception of holidays, vacations and periods of redecorating. The serving of such meals and food shall be the principal business conducted, with the serving of malt beverages and/or wine to be consumed on the premises as only incidental thereto. A restaurant shall derive at least 75 percent of its total annual gross food and beverages sales from the sale of prepared meals or prepared food and shall have food sales in excess of $100,000.00 per year. School means a building, publicly or privately owned, which is used for teaching or giving instruction in any subject to pupils of the school. Wholesaler or wholesale distributor means any person firm, or corporation engaged in distribution or selling to retailers for the purpose of resale any of the distilled spirits as defined in this section. Wine means the fermented juice of any fruit or plant having an alcoholic strength of no more than 21 percent alcohol by volume. (Code 1994 §§ 33-102, 33-202, 33-301, 33-303) Sec. 4-2. - Violation. Any violation of the provisions of this chapter shall subject the offender to punishment in accordance with section 1-8 for each violation in addition to such violation being a cause for revocation or suspension of the license of a licensee by the mayor and city council. (Code 1994 §§ 33-118, 33-219) Sec. 4-3. - Purpose. In accordance with the laws of the state, it is necessary and expedient for the city to establish and promulgate certain standards and regulations in regard to the sale, tax and control of distilled spirits, malt beverages, and wine in said city. This chapter does not permit the sale of distilled spirits by the drink or otherwise for consumption on the premises. Such sale of distilled spirits by the drink or otherwise for consumption on the premises is expressly prohibited. (Code 1994 §§ 33-101, 33-201) Sec. 4-4. - Application for a license. Application for a license shall be made on forms furnished by the mayor and city council as follows: (1) All applications for licenses shall be presented in person. (2) In addition to the completion and submission of an application form as required by the city, each applicant shall attach thereto a completed application form with all attachments and requirements for a state license. (3) Pursuant to state law, each applicant shall be required to furnish a complete set of fingerprints for each initial application for a license to be forwarded to the Georgia Bureau of Investigation. A previously fingerprinted licensee who desires to continue in business during subsequent calendar years without interruption at the same location shall not be required to furnish additional fingerprints for subsequent yearly applications involving the same type of license. (4) Before any distilled spirits, malt beverage and wine, or pouring license is granted, the applicant must post with the mayor and city council, along with his application, a performance bond with an insurance company, as surety. Said bond shall require the faithful observance and performance by the licensee of the rules and regulations contained in this chapter. Upon the violation of this chapter, or any part thereof, the amount of the bond to be forfeited will be determined by the seriousness of the violations as determined by the mayor and city council. The bond is to be approved by the mayor and city council and shall be properly executed. The bond is to be in the amount of $2,500.00 for a wholesale license, $500.00 for a retail license, or $1,000.00 for a pouring license. (5) A license shall be valid only for the calendar year indicated thereon and no such license may be renewed. A licensee who desires to continue in business during the next or subsequent calendar year must make a new application for such year on or before December 15 of the present year. (Code 1994 §§ 33-105, 33-205; Ord. of 7-18-2011, § 1) State law reference— Fingerprinting required for issuance of a permit or license, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-2(c). Sec. 4-5. - Display of license. Licenses under this chapter shall be displayed prominently at all times on the licensed premises. (Code 1994 §§ 33-109, 33-208, 33-325) Sec. 4-6. - Transferability. (a) Except as otherwise stated in this chapter, no license shall be transferable or assignable to any person or other location, and in the event that a licensed business is sold or closed, it shall be the duty of the licensee to immediately surrender his license to the mayor and city council. Under no circumstances will the license fee be refunded to the holder. (b) No license shall be transferred from one person to another during the year in which the license was obtained except in the case of the death of a person holding a license. In such a case, the licensee's executor or administrator may continue to operate under the license for up to six months from the date of qualification. (c) Upon the sale of any licensed business hereunder, the new owner may operate the business under the old license under this chapter, but in no event for longer than 60 days or until his application is granted or denied under this chapter, whichever shall first occur. (d) All holders of licenses issued under this chapter shall within six months after the issuance of such license open for business the establishment referred to in the license. Failure to open the licensed establishment within such period shall serve as a forfeiture and cancellation of the unused license and no refund of the license fee shall be made to the license holder. (Code 1994 §§ 33-113, 33-306, 33-213) Sec. 4-7. - Inspections. The business premises of the licensee shall be open to inspection at any and all times by officers or officials authorized to conduct such inspections. (Code 1994 §§ 33-114, 33-215, 33-320) Sec. 4-8. - Gambling. There shall be no gambling, betting, games of chance, punch-boards, vending machines, slot machines, pinball machines, lotteries, tickets, or chances therein or the operation of any schemes for hazarding money or any other thing of value in any licensee's place of business, or in any room adjoining the same, owned, leased or controlled by licensee. Provided, however, that the sale of Georgia lottery tickets in compliance with state law is permitted where alcoholic beverages are sold only for off-premises consumption. (Code 1994 §§ 33-115, 33-216, 33-323) State law reference— Lottery for education, O.C.G.A. § 50-27-1 et seq. Sec. 4-9. - Compliance with laws. In addition to the rules and regulations of this chapter, each licensee doing business in the city under this chapter shall comply with all laws of the state, all federal laws, and all rules and regulations of the state revenue commissioner relating to the sale and distribution of distilled spirits, malt beverages and/or wine in the state; and any violation of same shall subject the licensee to suspension or revocation of his license and also may subject the licensee to criminal prosecution by the proper authority as provided by law and ordinance of the city. (Code 1994 §§ 33-116, 33-217) Sec. 4-10. - Sales to minors. (a) Definition. The term "minor," as used in this section, means any person under the age of 21 years. (b) It shall be unlawful for a minor to attempt to purchase or for any other person to purchase for a minor distilled spirits, malt beverages, and/or wine. (c) It shall be unlawful for a minor to exhibit fake, forged, or borrowed credentials in an effort to obtain distilled spirits, malt beverages, and/or wine to which he is not legally entitled. (d) No person engaged in the business regulated hereunder shall make or permit to be made any sale of distilled spirits, malt beverages, and/or wine to minors. (e) No person shall allow anyone under 21 years of age to loiter about the premises of a licensee or possess any alcoholic beverage. This provision shall not apply to employees over the age of 18 eligible for employment under the laws of the state. (f) Any violations of the provisions of this section shall constitute a misdemeanor and the offender, upon being found guilty, shall be punishable as for a misdemeanor and by possible loss of license. (g) The prohibition contained in this section shall not apply with respect to the sale, purchase or possession of distilled spirits for consumption under the following circumstances: (1) For medical purposes pursuant to a prescription of a physician duly authorized to practice medicine in the state; (2) At a religious ceremony; or (3) In the minor's home with the consent of a parent or guardian and with a parent or guardian present. (Code 1994 §§ 33-117, 33-218, 33-331) Sec. 4-11. - Suspension or revocation of license. (a) No person shall engage in the sale of distilled spirits, malt beverages, and/or wine in the incorporated areas of the city without first complying with the rules and requirements set out in this chapter. Any license issued hereunder shall be subject to suspension or revocation upon any of the following grounds: (1) The making of any false statements on an application for a license issued hereunder; (2) A violation of the rules and regulations set out in this chapter and/or the laws and/or regulations of the United States and/or the state and/or the city; (3) The failure to have the financial responsibility upon which issuance of the license was conditioned; (4) Default in any obligation, of any kind whatsoever, lawfully owing to the city; (5) Suspension or revocation of a state retail distilled spirits or dealer's license; (6) Any violation of this chapter; or (7) For any other legal and sufficient case. (b) Any action taken by the mayor and city council to suspend or revoke a license issued hereunder shall not preclude and may be in addition to any criminal prosecution by a proper authority as provided by the laws and/or ordinances of the city, the state, and/or the United States. Whenever any action is taken by the mayor and city council to suspend or revoke any license issued hereunder, the mayor and city council shall provide written notice to the licensee of the action taken. The notice shall set forth the reasons for such action. The licensee shall have ten days following notification of such action to request a hearing before the mayor and city council. The licensee shall be entitled at such hearing to present evidence and cross examine opposing witnesses. (Code 1994 §§ 33-119, 33-220, 33-342) Sec. 4-12. - Production of records. In conjunction with any license application or any license issued under the terms hereof, or in conjunction with the revocation, suspension or cancellation of any license or in conjunction with any of the hearings contemplated by this chapter, or in conjunction with the payment or nonpayment of any excise tax levied or to be collected hereunder, the mayor and city council shall have the right to subpoena all or any part of the records, books, documents, reports or invoices of any applicant or licensee. Such subpoena right shall be had for the purposes of auditing the records of such applicant or licensee, securing compliance by such licensee with the provisions of this chapter, proving or disproving violation of any part of this chapter by any licensee, or to show payment or nonpayment of any taxes, fees, charges or the like due hereunder. (Code 1994 §§ 33-120, 33-221, 33-321) Sec. 4-13. - Conditions of premises. (a) All premises used for the sale of distilled spirits, malt beverages, and wine and/or for the storage of distilled spirits, malt beverages, and wine shall be kept in a sanitary condition and shall be kept in full compliance with the regulations of the county health department. (b) All premises shall be subject to inspection by the county health department, the city fire department, the city building inspector, and any authorized law enforcement officers to determine whether the premises are in compliance with all city, county and state rules, regulations, laws and codes. (Code 1994 §§ 33-121, 33-222, 33-333) Sec. 4-14. - Incorporation of state law. The state laws and/or regulations relating to the sale and/or distribution of alcoholic beverages within the state are hereby incorporated herein and made a part of this chapter as if fully set out herein. (Code 1994 §§ 33-122, 33-223, 33-335) Sec. 4-15. - Copy of chapter to be used for employee instruction. Licensees shall keep a copy of this chapter on the licensed premises and shall instruct any person working there with respect to the terms hereof, and the licensee and his agents and employees selling distilled spirits, malt beverages, and/or wine shall at all times be familiar with the terms hereof. The licensee shall be held responsible for any acts of his agents or employees in any violation of this chapter or of the laws of the state or the rules and regulations of the state revenue commissioner. (Code 1994 §§ 33-124, 33-225, 33-319) Sec. 4-16. - Posting of warning. The licensee shall post in a conspicuous place in his establishment a sign printed in letters at least four inches high reading as follows: "SALE OF ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES TO PERSONS UNDER 21 YEARS OF AGE STRICTLY PROHIBITED" and "SALE OF ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES ON SUNDAYS STRICTLY PROHIBITED." The licensee shall also post in a conspicuous place in the licensed premises a sign printed in letters at least four inches high reading as follows: "WARNING: DRINKING ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES DURING PREGNANCY CAN CAUSE BIRTH DEFECTS." (Code 1994 §§ 33-125, 33-226, 33-313) Sec. 4-17. - Prohibited sales. No licensee nor any agent or employee of a licensee shall furnish, sell or offer to sell any distilled spirits, malt beverage and/or wine to any person who is confined in any jail, penal institution, correctional facility, prison camp, penitentiary or other lawful place of confinement, or to any person who is a patient or inmate of the Central State Hospital, or to any person who is noticeably intoxicated, or is of unsound mind, or is a habitual drunkard whose intemperate habits are known to the licensee or the agent or employee. (Code 1994 §§ 33-126, 33-227, 33-314) Sec. 4-18. - Telephone. A licensee shall maintain on the premises at all times a telephone in good working order. (Code 1994 §§ 33-127, 33-228, 33-334) Secs. 4-19—4-39. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - DISTILLED SPIRITS
Sec. 4-40. - Off-premises consumption. Distilled spirits sold in the city will be for consumption only off the premises of the licensee. (Code 1994, § 33-103) Sec. 4-41. - Licensee qualifications. (a) No distilled spirits license shall be granted to any person unless such person is at least 25 years of age and has been a resident of the state for a minimum of a one-year period prior to filing an application for such license. In the event a corporation should be an applicant and the corporation has not been incorporated and/or allowed to do business by the Secretary of State for such one-year period, then the incorporator as agent of the corporation and the owners of at least 80 percent of the stock of the corporation shall all have been residents of the state for a one-year period prior to filing an application for such license. (b) No official or employees of the city, the state, or member of its mayor and city council, shall be eligible to receive a distilled spirits license; provided, however, that any nonprofit corporation whose earnings are purely civic and for community purposes may be organized or owned by or operated by members of the mayor and city council, and/or by officials or employees of the city as the case may be. (c) Pursuant to state law, no distilled spirits license shall be granted to any person unless the entire business premises of the proposed location is situated beyond 100 yards from the property line of any church and beyond 200 yards from the property line of any school ground or college campus and not less than 100 yards from any building used as an alcohol rehabilitation center. The same shall be measured by way of the most direct route of travel on the ground. Each application for a distilled spirits license shall include a scale drawing of the location of the proposed premises showing the distance to the nearest church, school and alcohol rehabilitation center or a certificate of a registered surveyor that such location complies with this section. State law reference— Sale of alcohol near churches, schools, or housing authority property, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-21. (d) A separate distilled spirits license shall be required for each place of business. (e) No distilled spirits license shall be issued to any person unless the building in which the business will be located is complete and detailed plans of the building and outside premises are attached to the application, or unless proposed plans and specifications and a building permit of a proposed building to be built are attached to the application. The completed building or the proposed building shall comply with all resolutions and ordinances of the city, all regulations of the state revenue commissioner, and all the laws of the state. The proposed building shall also be subject to final inspection and approval when completed by the building inspector. Each building in which the business is to be located shall contain sufficient lighting so that the building itself and the premises on all sides of the building shall be readily visible at all times from the front of the street on which the building is located. The lighting shall reveal the inside retail area of the building and shall reveal all of the outside premises of the building. Each applicant for a distilled spirits license shall attach to his application evidence of ownership of the building or proposed building or a copy of the lease if the applicant is leasing the building. (f) The licensee shall be responsible for the management and operation of the business for which the license is granted. (g) The applicant shall make a sworn statement of his qualifications according to this section and shall place the same on file with the city clerk/treasurer before any license is issued. (h) If the application covers a partnership, all members of the partnership must be qualified to obtain a license and must make sworn statements of these qualifications. (i) If the application covers a corporation, the manager of the proposed licensed premises must be qualified to obtain a license and must make sworn statements of these qualifications. A corporate license applicant shall appoint and designate to the mayor and city council an agent authorized to receive service of process under the laws of the state. If no such designation is made, the mayor and city council may serve or notify the applicant or license holder at any address of the applicant or license holder known to the mayor and city council. (j) No applicant who, within the ten years prior to the date of application, has a conviction of or has pled nolo contendere to a felony or a misdemeanor involving moral turpitude shall be granted a license if such conviction tends to indicate that the applicant would not maintain the operation for which a license is being sought in conformity with the laws and regulations of the federal or state governments, or the laws and regulations of the city. No license shall be granted to an applicant who has been convicted under any federal, state or local law for a criminal offense involving alcoholic beverages, gambling or tax law violations if such conviction tends to indicate that the applicant would not maintain the operation for which a license is being sought in conformity with the laws and regulations of the federal or state governments, or the laws and regulations of the city. (k) Any applicant denied a license shall be prohibited from applying for another license for a period of one year from the filing date set forth on the application. Any partnership, company, corporation, trust or other entity in which an individual applicant is a member, shareholder, director or officer, or in which such entity acts as a surrogate for such applicant, shall also be subject to the prohibition contained in this subsection. (l) The mayor and city council, in its discretion, may consider any and all relevant circumstances which may reflect favorably or unfavorably on the applicant, application or the proposed location of the business. If in its sole judgment, circumstances are such that the granting, suspension or revocation of the license would or would not be in the best interest of the general public, such circumstances may be grounds for the decision of the mayor and city council. (m) Any misstatement or concealment of fact in the application shall be grounds for revocation of the license issued and shall make the applicant liable to prosecution for perjury under the law of the state. (n) Whenever the mayor and city council shall deny an application for a distilled spirits license, the applicant shall have ten days following the date of notice of the denial to request a hearing before the mayor and city council. The applicant shall be entitled at such a hearing to present evidence and cross examine opposing witnesses. (Code 1994, § 33-104) Sec. 4-42. - License fee. The amount of the annual fee for a distilled spirits license shall be established by the city council from time to time and set forth in the schedule of fees and charges, available for examination in the office of the city clerk/treasurer. The fee shall be paid prior to the issuance of any license, such fee to accompany the application and shall be either in cash or a bank certified check. All licenses shall expire on December 31 of the year for which they were granted. No license fee shall be prorated. (Code 1994, § 33-106) Sec. 4-43. - Licensee regulations. No licensee, nor any agent or employee of the licensee nor any other person, shall do any of the following upon the licensed premises: (1) Sell or deliver any distilled spirits to any person except in the licensee's place of business. (2) Open his place of business, or furnish, sell or offer for sale any distilled spirits at any of the following times: a. On Sundays before the hour of 12:30 p.m. or after 11:30 p.m.; or b. At any time in violation of state law, state rules or regulations, local ordinances or regulations, or special orders of the mayor and city council; or c. On Monday through Saturday before 8:00 a.m. or after 11:45 p.m. (3) Sell or possess for the purpose of sale, any distilled spirits where such person does not have a license from the mayor and city council to sell or possess for sale such distilled spirits. (4) Receive or deliver distilled spirits at the premises of the licensee by means other than by a conveyance owned and operated by a wholesale dealer with a permit from the city to make deliveries in the city. (5) Knowingly and intentionally offer for sale, sell barter, exchange, give, provide or furnish distilled spirits to any person confined in any jail, penal institution, correctional facility, prison camp, penitentiary or other lawful place of confinement, or to any person who is a patient or inmate of the Central State Hospital, or to any person who is noticeably intoxicated, or who is of unsound mind, or is a habitual drunkard whose intemperate habits are known to such person. (6) Fail to post in a conspicuous place in the licensed premises a sign printed in letters at least four inches high reading as follows: "WARNING: DRINKING ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES DURING PREGNANCY CAN CAUSE BIRTH DEFECTS." (7) Fail to post in a conspicuous place in his establishment a sign printed in letters at least four inches high reading as follows: "SALE OF ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES TO PERSONS UNDER 21 YEARS OF AGE STRICTLY PROHIBITED" and "SALE OF ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES ON SUNDAYS STRICTLY PROHIBITED". (8) Fail to maintain on the licensed premises at all times a telephone in good working order. (9) Knowingly allow any person with a criminal record for violence or disorder to frequent the premises or loiter on the premises. (10) Knowingly allow any person to frequent the licensee's premises for the purpose of soliciting prostitution. (11) Fail to report to the police, at the earliest possible time, any known incidents of a criminal nature that happen on the licensee's premises. It shall be unlawful for any licensee to willfully withhold from the police any information pertaining to any crime that may have happened on the premises. (12) Knowingly allow any criminal act to be committed on the premises. (Code 1994, § 33-107; Ord. of 8-20-2012, §§ 1, 2) Sec. 4-44. - Limitations. (a) The city will issue not more than one distilled spirits license to the nearest 1,000 population residing within the corporate limits of the city by the last or any future decennial census of the United States. (b) All licensees shall sell or offer to sell distilled spirits in the original unbroken package only and shall sell no package containing less than one-half pint. (c) No licensee shall keep in stock, display, set or offer to sell, at any place of business licensed hereunder, any other product or commodity except the following: (1) Wines, when properly licensed; (2) Malt beverages, when properly licensed; (3) Non-alcohol beverages commonly used to dilute distilled spirits; (4) Tobacco products; (5) Ice to be sold in sealed containers only and not to be opened on the premises; (6) Paper, styrofoam or plastic cups; and (7) Distilled spirits. (d) Beverages containing no alcohol and commonly used to dilute distilled spirits may be dispensed through the use of vending machines, but no alcoholic beverages shall be dispensed through such vending machines. (e) No licensee shall keep any, distilled spirits stored in any bonded or other type of warehouse in the city, nor shall he enter into any type of arrangement whereby distilled spirits ordered by him are stored for him by any wholesaler. A licensee shall keep no inventory or stock of distilled spirits at any place except his licensed place of business, and within his licensed place of business his storage space for distilled spirits shall be immediately adjacent to the room in which he is licensed to do business. (Code 1994, § 33-108) Sec. 4-45. - Wholesale permits. Any wholesale distributor in distilled spirits licensed by the state or the agent of such licensed wholesale distributor may be granted a permit to distribute such distilled spirits in the city upon making application for such permit to the city clerk/treasurer and upon the presentation of evidence satisfactory to the city that the applicant understands and will comply fully with all terms and conditions and provisions of this article, as amended, and upon payment of an annual fee. The amount of the annual fee shall be established by the city council from time to time and set forth in the schedule of fees and charges, available for examination in the office of the city clerk/treasurer. (Code 1994, § 33-110) Sec. 4-46. - Taxes on distilled spirits. (a) There is hereby levied an excise tax computed at the rate of $0.22 per liter which shall be paid to the mayor and city council on all distilled spirits sold, displayed or stored in the city. The tax shall be paid to the mayor and city council by the wholesale distributor on all distilled spirits sold to retailers in the city as follows: Each wholesale distributor selling, shipping, or in any way delivering distilled spirits to any retailer, shall collect the excise tax at the time of delivery and shall remit the same together with a summary of all deliveries to each retailer on or before the tenth day of the month following. The $0.22 per liter shall be pro-rated so that each bottle or each individual size container shall be taxed on the basis of $0.22 per liter. It shall be unlawful and a violation of this section for any wholesale distributor to sell, ship, or deliver in any manner any distilled spirits to a retailer without having collected the tax. It shall be unlawful and a violation of this article for any retailer to possess, own, hold, store, display, or sell any distilled spirits on which such tax has not been paid. Each wholesaler shall be paid three percent of the amount of taxes collected as reimbursement for collection of the tax or such lesser amount set by state law. (b) Each wholesale distributor shall furnish to the mayor and city council a summary of all purchase invoices for distilled spirits sold to each retailer in the city on or before the 20th day of each month following such purchases. The summary shall show the amount of excise tax paid. (Code 1994, § 33-111) State law reference— Excise tax on distilled spirits, O.C.G.A. § 3-4-80. Sec. 4-47. - Financial responsibility. Any applicant for a distilled spirits license must show financial responsibility to the satisfaction of the mayor and city council. Financial statements must be submitted with each completed application as prescribed by the mayor and city council. Forms of same are to be furnished by the mayor and city council along with or included in application forms for licenses. Any applicant who becomes licensed must maintain a minimum of $20,000.00 stock of goods while the license is held by the licensee. The stock shall be subject to inventory audit at the end of each month. (Code 1994, § 33-112) Sec. 4-48. - Employees. (a) Every licensee under this article shall maintain at all times on the premises for which the license has been issued a list of all persons currently employed by such licensee at such premises, which list shall show the current full legal name, alias, date of birth, current address, current home telephone number and social security number of each employee. (b) The employee list shall be available during reasonable hours for inspection by any law enforcement officer or official or his designee. If so required by such person, an employee must submit to a fingerprint identification and criminal history check. (c) No minors shall be employed in any capacity in a place of business operated by a licensee where distilled spirits are sold. (d) The licensee shall not employ on the premises any person who in the preceding ten years has been convicted of a felony or misdemeanor involving moral turpitude in the state or who has been convicted of a crime outside the state which would be a felony or misdemeanor involving moral turpitude in the state. (Code 1994, § 33-123) Secs. 4-49—4-69. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - MALT BEVERAGES AND WINE
Sec. 4-70. - Off-premises consumption. Malt beverages and/or wine sold pursuant to a license granted under this article will be for consumption only off the premises of the licensee. (Code 1994, § 33-203) Sec. 4-71. - Licensee qualifications. (a) No malt beverage and wine license shall be granted to any person unless such person is at least 25 years of age and has been a resident of the state for a minimum of one year prior to filing an application for such license. In the event a corporation should be an applicant and the corporation has not been incorporated and/or allowed to do business in the state by the Secretary of State for such one-year period, then the incorporator of the corporation and the owners of at least 80 percent of the stock of said corporation shall all have been residents of the state for one year prior to filing an application for such license. (b) No officials or employees of the city or member of its mayor and city council shall be eligible to receive a retail malt beverage and wine license; provided, however, that any nonprofit corporation whose earnings are purely civic and for community purposes may be organized or owned by or operated by members of the mayor and city council and/or by officials or employees of the city as the case may be. (c) Pursuant to state law, no license shall be granted to any person unless the entire business premises of the proposed location is situated beyond 100 feet from the property line of any church and not less than 200 yards from any schoolyard or college campus, and not less than 100 yards from any building used as an alcohol rehabilitation center. The same shall be measured by the most direct route of travel on the ground. The mayor and city council may require each application for a retail malt beverage and wine license to include a scale drawing of the location of the proposed premises showing the distance to the nearest church, school, and alcohol rehabilitation center or a certificate of a registered surveyor that such location complies with this section. State law reference— Sale of alcohol near churches, schools, or housing authority property, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-21. (d) A separate license shall be required for such each place of business. (e) No license shall be issued to any person unless the building in which the business will be located is complete and detailed plans of the building and outside premises are attached to the application, or unless proposed plans and specifications and a building permit of a proposed building to be built are attached to the application. The completed building or the proposed building shall comply with all resolutions and ordinances of the city and regulations of the state revenue commissioner and the laws of the state. The proposed building shall also be subject to final inspection and approval, when completed, by the city building inspector. Each applicant for a license shall provide evidence of ownership of the building or proposed building or a copy of the lease, if the applicant is leasing the building. (f) The licensee shall be responsible for the management and operation of the business for which the license is granted. (g) The applicant shall make a sworn statement of his qualifications according to the this section and shall place the same on file with the city clerk/treasurer before any license is issued. (h) If the application covers a partnership, all members of the partnership must be qualified to obtain a license and must make sworn statements of these qualifications. (i) If the application covers a corporation, the manager of the proposed licensed premises must be qualified to obtain a license and must make a sworn statement of these qualifications. A corporate license applicant shall appoint and designate to the mayor and city council an agent authorized to receive service of process under the laws of the state. If no such designation is made, the mayor and city council may serve or notify the applicant or license holder at any address of the applicant or license holder known to the mayor and city council. (j) No applicant who, within ten years prior to the date of application has a conviction of or has pled nolo contendere to a felony or a misdemeanor involving moral turpitude shall be granted a license if such conviction tends to indicate that the applicant would not maintain the operation for which a license is being sought in conformity with the laws and regulations of the federal or state governments, or the laws and regulations of the city. No license shall be granted to an applicant who has been convicted under any federal, state or local law for a criminal offense involving alcoholic beverages, gambling or tax law violations if such conviction tends to indicate that the applicant would not maintain the operation for which a license is being sought in conformity with the laws and regulations of the federal or state governments, or the laws and regulations of the city. (k) Any applicant denied a license shall be prohibited from applying for another license for a period of one year from the filing date set forth on the application. Any partnership, company, corporation, trust or other entity in which an individual applicant is a member, shareholder, director or officer, or in which such entity acts as a surrogate for such applicant, shall also be subject to the prohibition contained in this subsection. (l) The mayor and city council, in its discretion, may consider any and all relevant circumstances which may reflect favorably or unfavorably on the applicant, application or the proposed location of the business. If in its sole judgment, circumstances are such that the granting, suspension or revocation of the license would or would not be in the best interest of the general public, such circumstances may be grounds for the decision of the mayor and city council. (m) Any misstatement or concealment of fact in the application shall be grounds for revocation of the license issued and shall make the applicant liable to prosecution for perjury under the law of the state. (n) Whenever the mayor and city council shall deny an application for a license or permit, the applicant shall have ten days following the date of notice of the denial to request a hearing before the mayor and city council. The applicant shall be entitled at such a hearing to present evidence and cross examine opposing witnesses. (Code 1994, § 33-204) Sec. 4-72. - License fee. The amount of the annual fee for a license shall be established by the city council from time to time and set forth in the schedule of fees and charges, available for examination in the office of the city clerk/treasurer. The fee shall be paid prior to the issuance of such license, the fee to accompany the application and shall be either in cash or bank certified check. All licenses shall expire on December 31 of the year for which they were granted. No license fee shall be prorated. (Code 1994, § 33-206) Sec. 4-73. - Licensee regulations. (a) No licensee shall sell or deliver any malt beverages and/or wine to any person except in the licensee's place of business. (b) No licensee shall furnish, sell or offer for sale any malt beverages or wine as follows: (1) On Monday through Saturday before 8:00 a.m. or after 11:45 p.m. (2) At any time in violation of state law, state rules or regulations, local ordinances or regulations of the mayor and city council. (3) On Sundays before the hour of 12:30 p.m. or after 11:30 p.m. (c) No person shall sell or possess for the purpose of sale, any malt beverages and/or wine where such person does not have a license from the mayor and city council to sell or possess for sale such malt beverages and/or wine. (d) No person may knowingly and intentionally offer for sale, sell, barter, exchange, give, provide or furnish malt beverages or wine to any person who is contained in any jail, penal institution, correction facility, prison camp, penitentiary or other lawful place of confinement, or to any person who is an inmate of the Central State Hospital, or is noticeably intoxicated, or who is of unsound mind, or is a habitual drunkard whose intemperate habits are known to the person. (e) The licensee shall post in a conspicuous place in the licensed premises a sign printed in letters at least four inches high reading as follows: "SALE OF ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES TO PERSONS UNDER 21 YEARS STRICTLY PROHIBITED" and "SALE OF ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES ON SUNDAYS STRICTLY PROHIBITED." (f) The licensee shall post in a conspicuous place in the licensed premises a sign printed in letters at least four inches high reading as follows: "WARNING: DRINKING ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES DURING PREGNANCY CAN CAUSE BIRTH DEFECTS." (g) It shall be unlawful for the licensee to fail to maintain on the licensed premises at all times a telephone in good working order. (h) It shall be unlawful for any licensee to knowingly allow any person with a criminal record for violence or disorder to frequent the licensed premises or loiter on the licensed premises. (i) It shall be unlawful for any licensee to knowingly allow any person to frequent the licensee's premises for the purpose of soliciting prostitution. (j) It shall be unlawful for any licensee to fail to report to the police at the earliest possible time any known incidents of a criminal nature that happen on the licensee's premises. It shall be unlawful for any licensee to willfully withhold from the police any information pertaining to any crime that may have happened on the licensed premises. (k) It shall be unlawful for any licensee to knowingly allow any criminal act to be committed on the licensed premises. (Code 1994, § 33-207; Ord. of 8-20-2012, §§ 3, 4) Sec. 4-74. - Wholesale permits. Any wholesale distributor in malt beverages and wine licensed by the state or the agent of such licensed wholesale distributor may be granted a permit to distribute such malt beverages and wine in the city upon application for such permit to the city clerk/treasurer, and, upon the presentation of evidence satisfactory to the city that the applicant understands and will comply with all terms and conditions and provisions of the article governing the sale of malt beverages and wine in the city as such article may be amended, including, but not limited to, those under which malt beverages and wine licenses are issued, and upon payment of an annual fee. The amount of the fee shall be established by the city council from time to time and set forth in the schedule of fees and charges, available for examination in the office of the city clerk/treasurer. (Code 1994, § 33-209) State law reference— Restriction on license fees, O.C.G.A. § 3-5-43. Sec. 4-75. - Taxes on malt beverages. Pursuant to state law, there is hereby levied upon wholesale malt beverages distributors a tax on malt beverages as follows: (1) Malt beverages, commonly known as tap or draft beer, sold in or from a barrel or bulk container, shall be at a rate of $6.00 on each container sold containing not more than 15½ gallons and a proportional tax at the same rate on all fractional parts of 15½ gallons. (2) When malt beverages are sold in bottles, cans, or other containers, except barrel or bulk containers, a tax of five cents per 12 ounces and a proportional tax at the same rate on all fractional parts of 12 ounces. (3) Each wholesale distributor shall furnish to the mayor and city council a report itemizing all purchase invoices for malt beverages sold to each licensee in the city, on or before the tenth day of the month following such purchase. The invoices shall show the amount of excise tax paid. (Code 1994, § 33-210) State law reference— Municipal excise tax, O.C.G.A. § 3-5-80; Excise tax to be paid by wholesale dealer, O.C.G.A. § 3-5-81. Sec. 4-76. - Taxes on wine. Pursuant to state law, there is hereby levied on the first sale or use of wine by the package a tax of $0.22 per liter and a proportionate tax at the rate on all fractional parts of a liter. Each month the first purchaser or user shall furnish to the mayor and city council a report itemizing each first purchase or use during the month. The report shall be furnished before the tenth day of the month following the month reported. The report shall show the amount of excise tax paid during the reported month. Pursuant to state law, no tax shall be levied by the mayor and city council with respect to: (1) Wine sold to and used by established and recognized churches and synagogues for use in sacramental services only; (2) Any sale of wine which is exempt from taxation by the state under the Constitution of the United States; (3) Wine sold to persons outside this state for resale or consumption outside this state; or (4) Wines which contain less than one-half of one percent alcohol by volume. (Code 1994, § 33-211) State law reference— Excise tax on wine, O.C.G.A. § 3-6-60; exemptions from excise tax, O.C.G.A. §§ 3-6-70, 3-6-71. Sec. 4-77. - Financial responsibility. Any applicant for a license must show financial responsibility to the satisfaction of the mayor and city council. Financial statements must be submitted with each completed application as prescribed by the mayor and city council. Forms of same are to be furnished by the mayor and city council along with or included in application forms for licenses. Any applicant who becomes licensed must maintain a minimum of $1,000.00 stock of goods while the license is held by the licensee. The stock shall be subject to inventory audit at the end of each month. (Code 1994, § 33-212) Sec. 4-78. - Transportation. (a) All malt beverages transported or delivered to a licensee in the city shall be packaged in the following manner: 7-, 8- or 12-ounce sealed containers packaged 4, 6, 12, or 24 per package; 16-ounce sealed containers package 6 per package; 24-ounce sealed containers packaged only by the full case; 32-ounce sealed containers packaged only by the case; and draft beer in sealed containers which contain one-half barrel (15½ gallons), one-quarter barrel (7¾ gallons) or any other size as draft beer as is normally sold, transported and delivered in sealed containers within the state. (b) All wine transported or delivered to a licensee in the city shall be packaged in containers specified in the Standards of Fill for Wine prescribed by the Department of the Treasury of the United States for wines shipped in interstate commerce. The federal regulations relating to Standards of Fill for Wine are adopted and incorporated by reference in this subsection. Wines manufactured and produced in the state shall be exempt from the provisions of this subsection to the extent that they are exempted from the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 3-6-28 as amended from time to time. (Code 1994, § 33-214) Sec. 4-79. - Employees. (a) Every licensee under this article shall maintain, at all times on the premises for which the license has been issued, a list of all persons currently employed by such licensee at such premises, which list shall show the current full legal name, alias, date of birth, current address, current home telephone number and social security number of each employee. (b) The employee list shall be available during reasonable hours for inspection by any law enforcement officer or city official or his designee. If so required by such person, an employee must submit to a fingerprint identification and criminal history check. (c) No person under 18 years of age shall be employed in any capacity in any place of business licensed under this article; provided, however, that persons under 18 years of age who are employed in supermarkets, convenience stores, breweries and drugstores may sell or handle malt beverages and wine which are sold pursuant to and in compliance with this article. (d) It shall be unlawful for any licensee to employ on the premises any person who, in the preceding ten years, has been convicted of a felony or misdemeanor involving moral turpitude in the state or who has been convicted of a crime outside the state which would be a felony or misdemeanor involving moral turpitude in the state. (Code 1994, § 33-224) Sec. 4-80. - Lock and key. All malt beverages and/or wine shall be under lock or fully covered by opaque material during those hours when their sale is not permitted. All malt beverages and/or wine owned or possessed contrary to the provisions of this article are hereby declared to be contraband and shall be seized by the proper authorities. (Code 1994, § 33-229) Secs. 4-81—4-103. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - POURING LICENSES
Sec. 4-104. - Unlawful sales without license. It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or offer to sell any malt beverage and/or wine for consumption on the premises without first complying with the rules and regulations set forth in this article. It shall be unlawful in any case for any person to sell or offer to sell any distilled spirits for consumption on the premises. The business of selling malt beverages and/or wine for consumption on the licensed premises is declared to be a privilege, not a right, and such privilege shall not be exercised in the city except as licensed under the terms of this article. (Code 1994, § 33-302) Sec. 4-105. - Applications. No malt beverages and/or wine shall be sold by the drink for consumption on the premises except under a pouring license granted by the mayor and city council. Application for such license may be made only on behalf of restaurants and private clubs located within the incorporated areas of the city and shall be made on forms provided by the mayor and city council, subject to the requirements of section 4-4. Any application for a license hereunder for a private club shall contain certified copies of all documents necessary for the mayor and city council to ascertain that the applicant meets the requirements of a private club as defined in this chapter. (Code 1994, § 33-303) Sec. 4-106. - Licensee qualifications. The following standards shall be applied to all decisions pertaining to the issuance or denial of licenses hereunder: (1) No pouring license shall be granted to any person or partnership unless the person or all partners shall be at least 25 years of age and has/have been a resident of the state for a minimum of one year prior to filing an application for such license. In the event a corporation should be an applicant and the corporation has not been incorporated and/or allowed to do business by the Secretary of State for said one-year period, then the incorporator of the corporation and the owners of at least 80 percent of the stock of the corporation shall all have been residents of the state for one year prior to filing an application for such license. (2) All applicants for a pouring license must show financial responsibility. The mayor and city council may require all applicants to provide financial statements and other evidence of financial responsibility in conjunction with the application. The form of the application shall be set by the mayor and city council, and must be fully completed by the applicant and filed by the applicant with the city clerk/treasurer of the mayor and city council. (3) No officials or employees of the city or members of its mayor and city council shall be eligible to receive a pouring license. However, a private club is not automatically disqualified from receiving a retail consumption license because such club is organized or owned by or operated by one or more members of the mayor and city council and/or employees of the city. (4) No pouring license shall be granted to any person unless the front door of the building at the proposed location is situated not less than 100 yards from the property line of any church or any building used as an alcohol rehabilitation center, and not less than 200 yards from any school ground or college campus. This distance is to be measured by the most direct route of travel on the ground. For purposes of this subsection, "the most direct route of travel on the ground," means the shortest route available to a pedestrian utilizing legal means of foot travel (i.e., sidewalks, crosswalks and road shoulders; not jaywalking). Each application for a license shall include a scale drawing of the location of the proposed premises showing the distance to the nearest church, school ground or college campus and alcohol rehabilitation center, or a certificate of a registered surveyor that such location complies with this section. (5) No pouring license shall be issued to any person unless complete and detailed diagrams of the building in which the business will be located and the outside premises are attached to the application, or unless proposed plans and specifications and a building permit of a proposed building to be built are attached to the application. The completed building or the proposed building shall comply with ordinances of the mayor and city council, regulations of the state revenue commissioner, and the laws of the state. Upon completion, the proposed building shall be subject to final inspection and approval by the city building inspector. Each applicant for a license shall attach to his application evidence of ownership of the building or proposed building or a copy of the lease if the applicant is leasing the building. Licensees shall provide on the premises for which the license is issued adequate sanitary toilet facilities as required by the city health and building codes, and the building shall be adequately illuminated so that all hallways, passage ways and open areas may be clearly seen by customers therein. (6) All applicants for a pouring license must be the owner or lessee of the premises to be used for the sale and consumption of malt beverages and wine, and must provide evidence of ownership of the premises in the form of a fully executed deed in recordable form, or, if applicant is leasing the premises, the applicant must provide a copy of the lease. (7) A separate pouring license shall be required for each pouring location of each place of business. Each license will enable the licensee to sell the malt beverages and wine for consumption only in the areas of the premises allowed by state laws and regulations. (8) All applicants must be persons operating as the proposed licensed place of business a "restaurant" or "private club" as defined in this chapter, except in the case of an exception under section 4-107. No lounges shall be permitted. (9) No applicant who, within the ten years prior to the date of application, has a conviction of or has pled nolo contendere to a felony or a misdemeanor involving moral turpitude shall be granted a license if such conviction tends to indicate that the applicant would not maintain the operation for which a license is being sought in conformity with the laws and regulations of the federal or state governments, or the laws and regulations of the city. No license shall be granted to an applicant who has been convicted under any federal, state or local law for a criminal offense involving alcoholic beverages, gambling or tax law violations if such conviction tends to indicate that the applicant would not maintain the operation for which a license is being sought in conformity with the laws and regulations of the federal or state governments, or the laws and regulations of the city. All operators, managers, clerks, and other employees must meet these requirements, as well. (10) Any applicant denied a license shall be prohibited from applying for another license for a period of one year from the filing date set forth on the application. Any partnership, company, corporation, trust or other entity in which an individual applicant is a member, shareholder, director or officer, or in which such entity acts as a surrogate for such applicant, shall also be subject to the prohibition contained in this subsection. (11) A license may be denied to any applicant where it appears that the applicant would not have adequate financial participation in the proposed business to direct and manage its affairs, or where it appears that the applicant is intended to be a mere surrogate for a person who would not otherwise qualify for a license for any reason whatsoever. (12) The mayor and city council, in its discretion, may consider any extenuating circumstances which may reflect favorably or unfavorably on the applicant's application or the proposed location of the business. If in the judgment of the mayor and city council circumstances are such that the granting of the license would not be in the best interest of the general public, such circumstances may be grounds for denying the application. (13) A corporate license applicant shall appoint and designate to the mayor and city council an agent authorized to receive service of process under the laws of the state. If no such designation is made, the mayor and city council may serve or notify the applicant or license holder at any address of the applicant or license holder known to the mayor and city council. (14) The mayor and city council shall give notice in writing to the applicant of any decision to grant or deny an application. The notice shall give the reasons for the decision. (15) Whenever the mayor and city council shall deny an application for a pouring license, the applicant shall have ten days following the date of notice of the denial to request a hearing before the mayor and city council. The applicant shall be entitled at such a hearing to present evidence and cross examine opposing witnesses. (Code 1994 §§ 33-304, 33-305, 33-307, 33-309, 33-310; Ord. of 12-20-2005(03), § 1) Sec. 4-107. - Temporary license. (a) Notwithstanding any other provision of this article, a person may apply as a qualified restaurant even though the establishment has not yet been in operation for the previous 12 months. Because it is not possible to determine if such restaurant has annual food sales which are 75 percent or more of its total gross sales and it is not possible to determine if such restaurant has annual food sales in excess of $50,000.00, the mayor and city council may in its discretion consider the size and seating capacity of the restaurant, the size and seating capacity of any lounge therein, the size and type of kitchen facilities and all other relevant factors to determine if it appears substantially likely that the restaurant will qualify for a license under this article. If the mayor and city council anticipate that the establishment will qualify for a license, they may vote to award the applicant a temporary license not to exceed 90 days. At or before the conclusion of the 90-day period, the mayor and city council shall use a pro rata analysis to determine if the applicant is operating a qualified restaurant as is defined in this chapter. If the mayor and city council has determined that the restaurant is qualified under this chapter, the applicant may make application for a license under section 4-105 (b) Notwithstanding any other provision of this article to the contrary, a nonprofit organization which has at least 50 members regularly paying monthly, quarterly, semiannual or annual dues and has received and has maintained approval from the United States Internal Revenue Service as a bona fide 501(c)(3) organization, and has not applied for a license under section 4-105, may apply for a special event license. To make application for such license, the organization must comply with all the following: (1) Make application at least 14 days prior to the first date of the proposed license period; and (2) Pay a fee per licensed event in an amount that shall be established by the city council from time to time and set forth in the schedule of fees and charges, available for examination in the office of the city clerk; and (3) Not hold more than 12 days and/or nights of such sales per calendar year nor make such sales on more than three consecutive days and/or nights; and (4) All sales of malt beverages and/or wine must be for fundraising, or to directly further the purpose of the organization, or made in conjunction with service of a meal; and (5) All sections of this article must be complied with except sections 4-105, 4-106, 4-109 and 4-111; and (6) Only one such permit shall be issued for any one location within the incorporated limits of the city and such location shall be stated in the application; and (7) All applicants for a license must be of good character, and all operators, managers, clerks or other employees shall be of good character. Furthermore, corporate or firm applicants shall also be of good business reputation; and (8) Whenever the mayor and city council shall deny an application for a license, the applicant shall have ten days following the date of notice of denial to request a hearing before the mayor and city council. The applicant shall be entitled at such a hearing to present evidence and cross examine opposing witnesses; and (9) No license under this section shall be transferable or assignable to any person or other location. Under no circumstances will the temporary license fee be refunded to the organization. (Code 1994, § 33-308) Sec. 4-108. - Days of operation. No licensee shall furnish, sell or offer for sale any malt beverages and/or wine under this article at any of the following times; (1) On Sundays before the hour of 12:30 p.m. or after 12:00 Midnight; or (2) At any time on Christmas Day; or (3) At any time in violation of a local ordinance or regulation or of a special order of the mayor and city council; or (4) At any time in violation of state law or regulation. (Code 1994, § 33-311; Ord. of 8-20-2012, § 5) Sec. 4-109. - Reports. (a) Each licensee under this article shall, as a condition of maintaining such license, file with the city clerk/treasurer within 30 days after the end of each calendar quarter: (1) A sworn statement of the licensee's sales during the preceding calendar quarter on forms approved by the city. The forms for such quarterly verified statements shall reflect the licensee's gross dollar sales amount for total sales for the applicable calendar quarter, the gross dollar sales amount for malt beverages and wine for the applicable calendar quarter, and gross dollar sales amount for food items for the applicable calendar quarter. (2) Certified copies of the licensee's state department of revenue sales and use tax monthly reports as filed with the state department of revenue for each month during the respective calendar quarter. (b) Any sale of a food or beverage containing any malt beverage and/or wine shall be deemed to be a sale solely of a malt beverage and/or wine, and such sale shall not be included as a "food sale" in the quarterly reports. The fact that the sale of food during any calendar quarter exceeds by three times the sales of malt beverages and/or wine shall not be conclusive that the licensee is meeting the requirements of operating a restaurant as defined in this chapter. However, the failure of the food sales to so exceed by three times the sale of malt beverages and wine shall be prima facie evidence that the establishment is not meeting the definition of a restaurant. (c) The quarterly statements shall be confidential in nature and shall not be open for public inspection except as otherwise required by law. Such forms shall be used solely by the mayor and city council for determination of whether or not the licensee remains qualified to hold its pouring license. Failure to timely file such statements shall be a violation of this article punishable by a fine of up to $500.00 and cause for revocation of the license granted under this article. (Code 1994, § 33-312) Sec. 4-110. - Unbroken packages. No licensee may sell malt beverages and/or wine in unbroken packages or in any quantity for other than consumption on the premises. (Code 1994, § 33-316) Sec. 4-111. - Annual fees. (a) The amount of the annual fee for a malt beverage and wine pouring license shall be established by the city council from time to time and set forth in the schedule of fees and charges, available for examination in the office of the city clerk/treasurer. The fee shall be paid prior to the issuance of any license. The fee shall accompany the application and shall be either a cash payment or a bank certified check. (b) No annual fee shall be prorated. (Code 1994, § 33-317) Sec. 4-112. - False statement grounds for revocation. The making of any false statement on an application for a pouring license shall constitute grounds for revocation of the license. (Code 1994, § 33-322) Sec. 4-113. - Soliciting prohibited. No retail licensee shall require, permit, suffer, encourage, or induce any employee or person to solicit in the licensed premises for himself or for any person other than the patron and guests of the patron, the purchase by the patron of any malt beverage and/or wine, or money with which to purchase the same; nor shall any licensee pay a commission or any other compensation to any person frequenting his establishment or to his agent or manager to solicit for himself or for others the purchase by the patron of malt beverage and/or wine. (Code 1994, § 33-324) Sec. 4-114. - Delivery off premises unlawful. It shall be unlawful for any licensee to make delivery of any malt beverage and/or wine except inside of the premises or area licensed for the sale thereof. It shall be unlawful for any such licensee to sell malt beverages and/or wine for consumption off the premises. (Code 1994, § 33-326) Sec. 4-115. - Persons with criminal record for violence or disorder. It shall be unlawful for any licensee to knowingly allow any person with a criminal record for violence or disorder to frequent the premises or loiter on the premises. (Code 1994, § 33-327) Sec. 4-116. - Prostitution unlawful. It shall be unlawful for any licensee to knowingly allow any person to frequent the licensee's premises for the purpose of soliciting prostitution. (Code 1994, § 33-328) Sec. 4-117. - Police reports. It shall be unlawful for any licensee to fail to report to the police at the earliest possible time any known incidents of a criminal nature that happen on the licensee's premises. It shall be unlawful for any licensee to willfully withhold from the police any information pertaining to any crime that may have happened on the premises. (Code 1994, § 33-329) Sec. 4-118. - Police records. (a) It shall be unlawful for any licensee to employ on the premises any person who, in the preceding ten years, has been convicted of a felony or misdemeanor involving moral turpitude in the state or who has been convicted of a crime outside the state which would be a felony or misdemeanor involving moral turpitude in the state. It shall also be unlawful for any licensee to knowingly allow any criminal act to be committed on the premises. (b) No applicant or licensee shall, within ten years prior the date of application, have been convicted of or pled nolo contendere to a felony or a misdemeanor involving moral turpitude, or any crime relating to the sale of alcoholic beverages. If the applicant or licensee is a partnership, all members of such partnership must meet this requirement. If the applicant or licensee is a corporation, all stockholders and officers of the corporation must meet this requirement. (Code 1994, § 33-330) Sec. 4-119. - Containers. It shall be unlawful for licensees or their agents or employees to add to the contents of a container or to refill empty containers or in any manner to misrepresent the quantity, quality or brand name of any malt beverage and/or wine. (Code 1994, § 33-332) Sec. 4-120. - Employees. (a) Every licensee under this article shall maintain at all times on the premises for which the license has been issued a list of all persons currently employed by such licensee at such premises, which list shall show the current full legal name, alias, date of birth, current address, current home telephone number and social security number of each employee. (b) The employee list shall be available during reasonable hours for inspection by any law enforcement officer or city official or his designee. If so required by such person, an employee must submit to a fingerprint identification and criminal history check. Every retail licensee shall cause each of the licensee's employees during the hours of his employment to be identified by a conspicuous label or badge upon which shall appear the employee's first name. (c) No person under 18 years of age shall be employed in any capacity in any place of business licensed under this article. (Code 1994, § 33-336) Sec. 4-121. - Promotions. No licensee or employee or agent of a licensee shall engage in any of the following practices in connection with the sale or other disposition of malt beverages and/or wine: (1) The giving away of any ticket, token or any other item that can be exchanged for any malt beverage and/or wine upon the purchase of any other malt beverage and/or wine; (2) The sale of two or more malt beverages and/or wine for a single price, or the sale of one serving of malt beverage and/or wine with a ticket, token or any other items redeemable for a subsequent serving of malt beverage and/or wine. Also prohibited hereunder is the sale of all such beverages a customer can or desires to drink at a single price. (Code 1994, § 33-337) Sec. 4-122. - Prohibited acts. (a) No licensee shall authorize or permit any patron or customer to bring onto the premises one or more alcoholic beverages purchased elsewhere, nor shall any such licensee authorize or permit any patron or customer to take out of the premises one or more alcoholic beverages. (b) No licensee shall authorize or permit any patron or customer to bring or carry any deadly weapon or firearm on the premises except a law enforcement officer or other person authorized by federal or state law to bring or carry any deadly weapon or firearm on the premises, nor shall the licensee act as a keeper, bailee or custodian of any kind of deadly weapon or firearm for any customer or patron. (Code 1994, § 33-338) Sec. 4-123. - Clearing service areas. All licensees shall remove or cause to be removed from the area of the premises utilized by the customers or patrons all malt beverages and/or wine within one-half hour after the times for last call specified in section 4-125. (Code 1994, § 33-339) Sec. 4-124. - Lock and key. All malt beverages and/or wine shall be under lock or fully covered by opaque material during those hours when their sale is not permitted. All malt beverages and/or wine owned or possessed contrary to the provisions of this article are hereby declared to be contraband and shall be seized by the proper authorities. (Code 1994, § 33-340) Sec. 4-125. - Hours. On Monday through Friday, no malt beverage and/or wine may be served before 8:00 a.m. on any day or after last call which shall be 2:00 a.m. On Saturday, no malt beverage and/or wine may be served before 8:00 a.m. on any day or after last call which shall be 12:00 Midnight. On Sunday, no malt beverage and/or wine may be served before 12:30 p.m. or after last call which shall be 12:00 Midnight. (Code 1994, § 33-341; Ord. of 8-20-2012, § 6)

div.head: Chapter 6 - AMUSEMENTS AND ENTERTAINMENTS
div.p:
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 6-1—6-17. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - ADULT ENTERTAINMENT
FOOTNOTE(S): --- (1) --- State Law reference— Authority to restrict adult entertainment establishments to certain zoning classifications, O.C.G.A. § 36-60-3(b). (Back) Sec. 6-18. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Adult bookstore means: (1) An establishment having a substantial or significant portion of its stock in trade, books, magazines or other periodicals which are distinguished or characterized by their emphasis on matter depicting, describing, or relating to specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas; or (2) An establishment with a segment or section, comprising five percent or more of its total floor space, devoted to the sale or display of such materials which are distinguished or characterized by their emphasis on matter depicting, describing, or relating to specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas. Adult dancing establishment means a business that features dancers displaying or exposing specified anatomical areas. Adult motion picture arcade means any place to which the public is permitted or invited wherein coins or slug-operated or electronically or mechanically controlled still or motion picture machines, projectors, or other image-producing devices are maintained to show images to five or fewer persons per machine at any one time and where the images so displayed are distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on depicting or describing specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas. Adult motion picture mini-theater means an enclosed building with a capacity of less than 50 persons used for commercially presenting material distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on matter depicting, describing, or relating to specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas for observation by patrons therein. Adult motion picture theater means an enclosed building with a capacity of 50 or more persons used for commercially presenting material distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on matter depicting, describing, or relating to specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas for observation by patrons therein. Adult video store means: (1) An establishment having as its stock in trade in videotapes or movies or other reproductions, whether for sale or rent, which are distinguished or characterized by their emphasis on matter depicting, describing, or relating to specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas; or (2) An establishment with a segment or section, comprising five percent or more of its total floor space, devoted to the sale or display of such material; or (3) An establishment which derives more than five percent of its net sales from videos or movies or other reproductions which are characterized or distinguished by their emphasis on matter depicting, describing, or relating to specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas. Erotic dance establishment means a nightclub, theater, or other establishment which features live performances by topless and/or bottomless dancers, go-go dancers, strippers, or similar entertainers, where such performances are distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas. Escort bureau/introduction services mean any business, agency, or persons who, for a fee, commission, hire, reward or profit, furnish or offer to furnish names of persons, or who introduce, furnish or arrange for persons who may accompany other persons to or about social affairs, entertainments, or places of amusement, or who may consort with others about any place of public resort or within any private quarters. Good moral character means a person that has not been convicted of a felony or a misdemeanor involving moral turpitude in the past five years. The city may also take into account the length of time since any conviction of a felony or a crime involving moral turpitude, efforts by the applicant or employee to rehabilitate himself, the number of such convictions of the applicant or employee and the status of any sentence or probation imposed upon the applicant or employee for any such felony or crime involving moral turpitude. Conviction shall include pleas of nolo contendere or bond forfeiture. Licensee means a holder of a current, valid adult entertainment establishment license. Minor means any person who has not attained the age of 18 years. Specified anatomical areas includes any of the following: (1) Less than completely and opaquely covered human genitals or pubic region; buttock; or female breast below a point immediately above the top of the areola; or (2) Human male genitalia in a discernible turgid state, even if completely and opaquely covered. Specified sexual activities includes any of the following: (1) Actual or simulated sexual intercourse, oral copulation, anal intercourse, oral anal copulation, bestiality, direct physical stimulation of unclothed genitals, flagellation or torture in the context of a sexual relationship, or the use of excretory functions in the context of a sexual relationship and any of the following sexually oriented acts or conduct; anilingus, buggery, coprophagy, coprophilia, cunnilingus, fellatio, necrophilia, pederasty, pedophilia, piquerism, sapphism, or zooerasty; or (2) Clearly depicting human genitals in a state of sexual stimulation, arousal or tumescence; or (3) Human or animal ejaculation, sodomy, oral copulation, coitus or masturbation; or (4) Fondling or touching of nude human genitals, pubic region, buttocks or female breast; or (5) Masochism, erotic or sexually oriented torture, beating or the infliction of pain; or (6) Erotic or lewd touching, fondling or other sexual contact with an animal by a human being; or (7) Human excretion, urination, menstruation, vaginal or anal irrigation. (Code 1994, § 29-102) Sec. 6-19. - Penalty for violations. Any licensee or nonlicensee violating the provisions of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, punishable in accordance with section 1-8.
